method.autodoc: FindMenuItem(self, String menu, String item) -> int

constructor.name: MenuItem
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, Menu parentMenu=None, int id=ID_ANY, String text=EmptyString, String help=EmptyString, int kind=ITEM_NORMAL, Menu subMenu=None) -> MenuItem

class.name: Control
class.docstring:
This is the base class for a control or 'widget'.
A control is generally a small window which processes user input and/or displays one or more item of data.

constructor.name: Control
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, Window parent, int id=-1, Point pos=DefaultPosition, Size size=DefaultSize, long style=0, Validator validator=DefaultValidator, String name=ControlNameStr) -> Control
constructor.docstring: Create a Control. Normally you should only call this from a subclass' __init__ as a plain old wx.Control is not very useful.

constructor.name: PreControl
constructor.docstring: Precreate a Control control for 2-phase creation

method.name: Create
method.autodoc: Create(self, Window parent, int id=-1, Point pos=DefaultPosition, Size size=DefaultSize, long style=0, Validator validator=DefaultValidator, String name=ControlNameStr) -> bool
method.docstring: Do the 2nd phase and create the GUI control.

method.name: Command
method.docstring:
Simulates the effect of the user issuing a command to the item.
:see: `wx.CommandEvent`

method.name: GetLabel
method.docstring: Return a control's text.

method.name: SetLabel
method.docstring: Sets the item's text.

staticmethod.name: GetClassDefaultAttributes
staticmethod.docstring:
Get the default attributes for this class. This is useful if you want to use the same font or colour in your own control as in a standard control -- which is a much better idea than hard coding specific colours or fonts which might look completely out of place on the user's system, especially if it uses themes.
The variant parameter is only relevant under Mac currently and is ignore under other platforms. Under Mac, it will change the size of the returned font. See `wx.Window.SetWindowVariant` for more about this.

class.name: ItemContainer
class.docstring:
wx.ItemContainer defines an interface which is implemented by all controls which have string subitems, each of which may be selected, such as `wx.ListBox`, `wx.CheckListBox`, `wx.Choice` as well as `wx.ComboBox` which implements an extended interface deriving from this one.
It defines the methods for accessing the control's items and although each of the derived classes implements them differently, they still all conform to the same interface.
The items in a wx.ItemContainer have (non empty) string labels and, optionally, client data associated with them.

method.name: Append
method.autodoc: Append(self, String item, PyObject clientData=None) -> int
method.docstring: Adds the item to the control, associating the given data with the item if not None. The return value is the index of the newly added item which may be different from the last one if the control is sorted (e.g. has wx.LB_SORT or wx.CB_SORT style).

method.name: AppendItems
method.docstring: Apend several items at once to the control. Notice that calling this method may be much faster than appending the items one by one if you need to add a lot of items.

method.name: Insert
method.autodoc: Insert(self, String item, int pos, PyObject clientData=None) -> int
method.docstring: Insert an item into the control before the item at the ``pos`` index, optionally associating some data object with the item.

method.name: Clear
method.docstring: Removes all items from the control.

method.name: Delete
method.docstring: Deletes the item at the zero-based index 'n' from the control. Note that it is an error (signalled by a `wx.PyAssertionError` exception if enabled) to remove an item with the index negative or greater or equal than the number of items in the control.

method.name: GetCount
method.docstring: Returns the number of items in the control.

method.name: IsEmpty
method.docstring: Returns True if the control is empty or False if it has some items.

method.name: GetString
method.docstring: Returns the label of the item with the given index.

method.name: SetString
method.docstring: Sets the label for the given item.

method.name: FindString
method.docstring: Finds an item whose label matches the given string. Returns the zero-based position of the item, or ``wx.NOT_FOUND`` if the string was not found.

method.name: Select
method.docstring: Sets the item at index 'n' to be the selected item.

method.name: GetSelection
method.docstring: Returns the index of the selected item or ``wx.NOT_FOUND`` if no item is selected.

method.name: GetStringSelection
method.docstring: Returns the label of the selected item or an empty string if no item is selected.

method.name: GetClientData
method.docstring: Returns the client data associated with the given item, (if any.)

method.name: SetClientData
method.docstring: Associate the given client data with the item at position n.

class.name: ControlWithItems
class.docstring: wx.ControlWithItems combines the ``wx.ItemContainer`` class with the wx.Control class, and is used for the base class of various controls that have items.

class.name: SizerItem
class.docstring:
The wx.SizerItem class is used to track the position, size and other attributes of each item managed by a `wx.Sizer`. In normal usage user code should never need to deal directly with a wx.SizerItem, but custom classes derived from `wx.PySizer` will probably need to use the collection of wx.SizerItems held by wx.Sizer when calculating layout.
:see: `wx.Sizer`, `wx.GBSizerItem`

constructor.name: SizerItem
constructor.docstring:
Constructs an empty wx.SizerItem. Either a window, sizer or spacer size will need to be set before this item can be used in a Sizer.
You will probably never need to create a wx.SizerItem directly as they are created automatically when the sizer's Add, Insert or Prepend methods are called.
:see: `wx.SizerItemSpacer`, `wx.SizerItemWindow`, `wx.SizerItemSizer`

constructor.name: SizerItemWindow
constructor.autodoc: SizerItemWindow(Window window, int proportion, int flag, int border, PyObject userData=None) -> SizerItem
constructor.docstring: Constructs a `wx.SizerItem` for tracking a window.

constructor.name: SizerItemSpacer
constructor.autodoc: SizerItemSpacer(int width, int height, int proportion, int flag, int border, PyObject userData=None) -> SizerItem
constructor.docstring: Constructs a `wx.SizerItem` for tracking a spacer.

constructor.name: SizerItemSizer
constructor.autodoc: SizerItemSizer(Sizer sizer, int proportion, int flag, int border, PyObject userData=None) -> SizerItem
constructor.docstring: Constructs a `wx.SizerItem` for tracking a subsizer

method.name: DeleteWindows
method.docstring: Destroy the window or the windows in a subsizer, depending on the type of item.

method.name: DetachSizer
method.docstring: Enable deleting the SizerItem without destroying the contained sizer.

method.name: GetSize
method.docstring: Get the current size of the item, as set in the last Layout.

method.name: CalcMin
method.docstring: Calculates the minimum desired size for the item, including any space needed by borders.

method.name: SetDimension
method.docstring: Set the position and size of the space allocated for this item by the sizer, and adjust the position and size of the item (window or subsizer) to be within that space taking alignment and borders into account.

method.name: GetMinSize
method.docstring: Get the minimum size needed for the item.

method.name: SetRatioWH
method.docstring: Set the ratio item attribute.

method.name: SetRatioSize
method.docstring: Set the ratio item attribute.

method.name: SetRatio
method.docstring: Set the ratio item attribute.

method.name: GetRatio
method.docstring: Set the ratio item attribute.

method.name: IsWindow
method.docstring: Is this sizer item a window?

method.name: IsSizer
method.docstring: Is this sizer item a subsizer?

method.name: IsSpacer
method.docstring: Is this sizer item a spacer?

method.name: SetProportion
method.docstring: Set the proportion value for this item.

method.name: GetProportion
method.docstring: Get the proportion value for this item.

method.name: SetFlag
method.docstring: Set the flag value for this item.

method.name: GetFlag
method.docstring: Get the flag value for this item.

method.name: SetBorder
method.docstring: Set the border value for this item.

method.name: GetBorder
method.docstring: Get the border value for this item.

method.name: GetWindow
method.docstring: Get the window (if any) that is managed by this sizer item.

method.name: SetWindow
method.docstring: Set the window to be managed by this sizer item.

method.name: GetSizer
method.docstring: Get the subsizer (if any) that is managed by this sizer item.

method.name: SetSizer
method.docstring: Set the subsizer to be managed by this sizer item.

method.name: GetSpacer
method.docstring: Get the size of the spacer managed by this sizer item.

method.name: SetSpacer
method.docstring: Set the size of the spacer to be managed by this sizer item.

method.name: Show
method.docstring: Set the show item attribute, which sizers use to determine if the item is to be made part of the layout or not. If the item is tracking a window then it is shown or hidden as needed.

method.name: IsShown
method.docstring: Is the item to be shown in the layout?

method.name: GetPosition
method.docstring: Returns the current position of the item, as set in the last Layout.

method.name: GetUserData
method.docstring: Returns the userData associated with this sizer item, or None if there isn't any.

class.name: Sizer
class.docstring:
wx.Sizer is the abstract base class used for laying out subwindows in a window. You cannot use wx.Sizer directly; instead, you will have to use one of the sizer classes derived from it such as `wx.BoxSizer`, `wx.StaticBoxSizer`, `wx.NotebookSizer`, `wx.GridSizer`, `wx.FlexGridSizer` and `wx.GridBagSizer`.
The concept implemented by sizers in wxWidgets is closely related to layout tools in other GUI toolkits, such as Java's AWT, the GTK toolkit or the Qt toolkit. It is based upon the idea of the individual subwindows reporting their minimal required size and their ability to get stretched if the size of the parent window has changed. This will most often mean that the programmer does not set the original size of a dialog in the beginning, rather the dialog will assigned a sizer and this sizer will be queried about the recommended size. The sizer in turn will query its children, which can be normal windows or contorls, empty space or other sizers, so that a hierarchy of sizers can be constructed. Note that wxSizer does not derive from wxWindow and thus do not interfere with tab ordering and requires very little resources compared to a real window on screen.
What makes sizers so well fitted for use in wxWidgets is the fact that every control reports its own minimal size and the algorithm can handle differences in font sizes or different window (dialog item) sizes on different platforms without problems. If for example the standard font as well as the overall design of Mac widgets requires more space than on Windows, then the initial size of a dialog using a sizer will automatically be bigger on Mac than on Windows.

method.name: Add
method.autodoc: Add(self, item, int proportion=0, int flag=0, int border=0, PyObject userData=None)
method.docstring: Appends a child item to the sizer.

method.name: Insert
method.autodoc: Insert(self, int before, item, int proportion=0, int flag=0, int border=0, PyObject userData=None)
method.docstring: Inserts a new item into the list of items managed by this sizer before the item at index *before*. See `Add` for a description of the parameters.

method.name: Prepend
method.autodoc: Prepend(self, item, int proportion=0, int flag=0, int border=0, PyObject userData=None)
method.docstring: Adds a new item to the begining of the list of sizer items managed by this sizer. See `Add` for a description of the parameters.

method.name: Remove
method.docstring: Removes an item from the sizer and destroys it. This method does not cause any layout or resizing to take place, call `Layout` to update the layout on screen after removing a child from the sizer. The *item* parameter can be either a window, a sizer, or the zero-based index of an item to remove. Returns True if the child item was found and removed.

method.name: Detach
method.docstring: Detaches an item from the sizer without destroying it. This method does not cause any layout or resizing to take place, call `Layout` to do so. The *item* parameter can be either a window, a sizer, or the zero-based index of the item to be detached. Returns True if the child item was found and detached.

method.name: AddItem
method.docstring: Adds a `wx.SizerItem` to the sizer.

method.name: InsertItem
method.docstring: Inserts a `wx.SizerItem` to the sizer at the position given by *index*.

method.name: PrependItem
method.docstring: Prepends a `wx.SizerItem` to the sizer.

method.name: SetDimension
method.autodoc: SetDimension(self, int x, int y, int width, int height)
method.docstring: Call this to force the sizer to take the given dimension and thus force the items owned by the sizer to resize themselves according to the rules defined by the parameter in the `Add`, `Insert` or `Prepend` methods.

method.name: SetMinSize
method.docstring: Call this to give the sizer a minimal size. Normally, the sizer will calculate its minimal size based purely on how much space its children need. After calling this method `GetMinSize` will return either the minimal size as requested by its children or the minimal size set here, depending on which is bigger.

method.name: GetSize
method.docstring: Returns the current size of the space managed by the sizer.

method.name: GetPosition
method.docstring: Returns the current position of the sizer's managed space.

method.name: GetMinSize
method.docstring: Returns the minimal size of the sizer. This is either the combined minimal size of all the children and their borders or the minimal size set by SetMinSize, depending on which is bigger.

method.name: RecalcSizes
method.docstring: Using the sizes calculated by `CalcMin` reposition and resize all the items managed by this sizer. You should not need to call this directly as it is called by `Layout`.

method.name: CalcMin
method.docstring: This method is where the sizer will do the actual calculation of its children's minimal sizes. You should not need to call this directly as it is called by `Layout`.

method.name: Layout
method.docstring: This method will force the recalculation and layout of the items controlled by the sizer using the current space allocated to the sizer. Normally this is called automatically from the owning window's EVT_SIZE handler, but it is also useful to call it from user code when one of the items in a sizer change size, or items are added or removed.

method.name: Fit
method.docstring:
Tell the sizer to resize the *window* to match the sizer's minimal size. This is commonly done in the constructor of the window itself in order to set its initial size to match the needs of the children as determined by the sizer. Returns the new size.
For a top level window this is the total window size, not the client size.

method.name: FitInside
method.docstring:
Tell the sizer to resize the *virtual size* of the *window* to match the sizer's minimal size. This will not alter the on screen size of the window, but may cause the addition/removal/alteration of scrollbars required to view the virtual area in windows which manage it.
:see: `wx.ScrolledWindow.SetScrollbars`, `SetVirtualSizeHints`

method.name: SetSizeHints
method.docstring: Tell the sizer to set (and `Fit`) the minimal size of the *window* to match the sizer's minimal size. This is commonly done in the constructor of the window itself if the window is resizable (as are many dialogs under Unix and frames on probably all platforms) in order to prevent the window from being sized smaller than the minimal size required by the sizer.

method.name: SetVirtualSizeHints
method.docstring:
Tell the sizer to set the minimal size of the window virtual area to match the sizer's minimal size. For windows with managed scrollbars this will set them appropriately.
:see: `wx.ScrolledWindow.SetScrollbars`

method.name: Clear
method.docstring: Clear all items from the sizer, optionally destroying the window items as well.

method.name: DeleteWindows
method.docstring: Destroy all windows managed by the sizer.

method.name: GetChildren
method.docstring: Returns a list of all the `wx.SizerItem` objects managed by the sizer.

method.name: Show
method.docstring: Shows or hides an item managed by the sizer. To make a sizer item disappear or reappear, use Show followed by `Layout`. The *item* parameter can be either a window, a sizer, or the zero-based index of the item.

method.name: IsShown
method.docstring: Determines if the item is currently shown. sizer. To make a sizer item disappear or reappear, use Show followed by `Layout`. The *item* parameter can be either a window, a sizer, or the zero-based index of the item.

method.name: ShowItems
method.docstring: Recursively call `wx.Window.Show` on all sizer items.

class.name: PySizer

constructor.name: PySizer
constructor.docstring: Creates a wx.PySizer. Must be called from the __init__ in the derived class.

class.name: BoxSizer
class.docstring: The basic idea behind a box sizer is that windows will most often be laid out in rather simple basic geometry, typically in a row or a column or nested hierarchies of either. A wx.BoxSizer will lay out its items in a simple row or column, depending on the orientation parameter passed to the constructor.

constructor.name: BoxSizer
constructor.docstring: Constructor for a wx.BoxSizer. *orient* may be one of ``wx.VERTICAL`` or ``wx.HORIZONTAL`` for creating either a column sizer or a row sizer.

method.name: GetOrientation
method.docstring: Returns the current orientation of the sizer.

method.name: SetOrientation
method.docstring: Resets the orientation of the sizer.

class.name: StaticBoxSizer
class.docstring: wx.StaticBoxSizer derives from and functions identically to the `wx.BoxSizer` and adds a `wx.StaticBox` around the items that the sizer manages. Note that this static box must be created separately and passed to the sizer constructor.

constructor.name: StaticBoxSizer
constructor.docstring: Constructor. It takes an associated static box and the orientation *orient* as parameters - orient can be either of ``wx.VERTICAL`` or ``wx.HORIZONTAL``.

method.name: GetStaticBox
method.docstring: Returns the static box associated with this sizer.

class.name: GridSizer
class.docstring:
A grid sizer is a sizer which lays out its children in a two-dimensional table with all cells having the same size. In other words, the width of each cell within the grid is the width of the widest item added to the sizer and the height of each grid cell is the height of the tallest item. An optional vertical and/or horizontal gap between items can also be specified (in pixels.)
Items are placed in the cells of the grid in the order they are added, in row-major order. In other words, the first row is filled first, then the second, and so on until all items have been added. (If neccessary, additional rows will be added as items are added.) If you need to have greater control over the cells that items are placed in then use the `wx.GridBagSizer`.

constructor.name: GridSizer
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, int rows=1, int cols=0, int vgap=0, int hgap=0) -> GridSizer
constructor.docstring: Constructor for a wx.GridSizer. *rows* and *cols* determine the number of columns and rows in the sizer - if either of the parameters is zero, it will be calculated to from the total number of children in the sizer, thus making the sizer grow dynamically. *vgap* and *hgap* define extra space between all children.

method.name: SetCols
method.docstring: Sets the number of columns in the sizer.

method.name: SetRows
method.docstring: Sets the number of rows in the sizer.

method.name: SetVGap
method.docstring: Sets the vertical gap (in pixels) between the cells in the sizer.

method.name: SetHGap
method.docstring: Sets the horizontal gap (in pixels) between cells in the sizer

method.name: GetCols
method.docstring: Returns the number of columns in the sizer.

method.name: GetRows
method.docstring: Returns the number of rows in the sizer.

method.name: GetVGap
method.docstring: Returns the vertical gap (in pixels) between the cells in the sizer.

method.name: GetHGap
method.docstring: Returns the horizontal gap (in pixels) between cells in the sizer.

class.name: FlexGridSizer
class.docstring:
A flex grid sizer is a sizer which lays out its children in a two-dimensional table with all table cells in one row having the same height and all cells in one column having the same width, but all rows or all columns are not necessarily the same height or width as in the `wx.GridSizer`.
wx.FlexGridSizer can also size items equally in one direction but unequally ("flexibly") in the other. If the sizer is only flexible in one direction (this can be changed using `SetFlexibleDirection`), it needs to be decided how the sizer should grow in the other ("non flexible") direction in order to fill the available space. The `SetNonFlexibleGrowMode` method serves this purpose.

constructor.name: FlexGridSizer
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, int rows=1, int cols=0, int vgap=0, int hgap=0) -> FlexGridSizer
constructor.docstring: Constructor for a wx.FlexGridSizer. *rows* and *cols* determine the number of columns and rows in the sizer - if either of the parameters is zero, it will be calculated to from the total number of children in the sizer, thus making the sizer grow dynamically. *vgap* and *hgap* define extra space between all children.

method.name: AddGrowableRow
method.docstring:
Specifies that row *idx* (starting from zero) should be grown if there is extra space available to the sizer.
The *proportion* parameter has the same meaning as the stretch factor for the box sizers except that if all proportions are 0, then all columns are resized equally (instead of not being resized at all).

method.name: RemoveGrowableRow
method.docstring: Specifies that row *idx* is no longer growable.

method.name: AddGrowableCol
method.docstring:
Specifies that column *idx* (starting from zero) should be grown if there is extra space available to the sizer.
The *proportion* parameter has the same meaning as the stretch factor for the box sizers except that if all proportions are 0, then all columns are resized equally (instead of not being resized at all).

method.name: RemoveGrowableCol
method.docstring: Specifies that column *idx* is no longer growable.

method.name: SetFlexibleDirection
method.docstring:
Specifies whether the sizer should flexibly resize its columns, rows, or both. Argument *direction* can be one of the following values. Any other value is ignored.
============== ======================================= wx.VERTICAL Rows are flexibly sized. wx.HORIZONTAL Columns are flexibly sized. wx.BOTH Both rows and columns are flexibly sized (this is the default value). ============== =======================================
Note that this method does not trigger relayout.

method.name: GetFlexibleDirection
method.docstring:
Returns a value that specifies whether the sizer flexibly resizes its columns, rows, or both (default).
:see: `SetFlexibleDirection`

method.name: SetNonFlexibleGrowMode
method.docstring:
Specifies how the sizer should grow in the non-flexible direction if there is one (so `SetFlexibleDirection` must have been called previously). Argument *mode* can be one of the following values:
========================== ================================================= wx.FLEX_GROWMODE_NONE Sizer doesn't grow in the non flexible direction. wx.FLEX_GROWMODE_SPECIFIED Sizer honors growable columns/rows set with `AddGrowableCol` and `AddGrowableRow`. In this case equal sizing applies to minimum sizes of columns or rows (this is the default value). wx.FLEX_GROWMODE_ALL Sizer equally stretches all columns or rows in the non flexible direction, whether they are growable or not in the flexbile direction. ========================== =================================================
Note that this method does not trigger relayout.

method.name: GetNonFlexibleGrowMode
method.docstring:
Returns the value that specifies how the sizer grows in the non-flexible direction if there is one.
:see: `SetNonFlexibleGrowMode`

class.name: GBPosition
class.docstring: This class represents the position of an item in a virtual grid of rows and columns managed by a `wx.GridBagSizer`. wxPython has typemaps that will automatically convert from a 2-element sequence of integers to a wx.GBPosition, so you can use the more pythonic representation of the position nearly transparently in Python code.

constructor.name: GBPosition
constructor.docstring: This class represents the position of an item in a virtual grid of rows and columns managed by a `wx.GridBagSizer`. wxPython has typemaps that will automatically convert from a 2-element sequence of integers to a wx.GBPosition, so you can use the more pythonic representation of the position nearly transparently in Python code.

class.name: GBSpan
class.docstring: This class is used to hold the row and column spanning attributes of items in a `wx.GridBagSizer`. wxPython has typemaps that will automatically convert from a 2-element sequence of integers to a wx.GBSpan, so you can use the more pythonic representation of the span nearly transparently in Python code.

constructor.name: GBSpan
constructor.docstring: Construct a new wxGBSpan, optionally setting the rowspan and colspan. The default is (1,1). (Meaning that the item occupies one cell in each direction.

class.name: GBSizerItem
class.docstring: The wx.GBSizerItem class is used to track the additional data about items in a `wx.GridBagSizer` such as the item's position in the grid and how many rows or columns it spans.

constructor.name: GBSizerItem
constructor.docstring:
Constructs an empty wx.GBSizerItem. Either a window, sizer or spacer size will need to be set, as well as a position and span before this item can be used in a Sizer.
You will probably never need to create a wx.GBSizerItem directly as they are created automatically when the sizer's Add method is called.

constructor.name: GBSizerItemWindow
constructor.autodoc: GBSizerItemWindow(Window window, GBPosition pos, GBSpan span, int flag, int border, PyObject userData=None) -> GBSizerItem
constructor.docstring: Construct a `wx.GBSizerItem` for a window.

constructor.name: GBSizerItemSizer
constructor.autodoc: GBSizerItemSizer(Sizer sizer, GBPosition pos, GBSpan span, int flag, int border, PyObject userData=None) -> GBSizerItem
constructor.docstring: Construct a `wx.GBSizerItem` for a sizer

constructor.name: GBSizerItemSpacer
constructor.autodoc: GBSizerItemSpacer(int width, int height, GBPosition pos, GBSpan span, int flag, int border, PyObject userData=None) -> GBSizerItem
constructor.docstring: Construct a `wx.GBSizerItem` for a spacer.

method.name: GetPos
method.docstring: Get the grid position of the item

method.name: GetSpan
method.docstring: Get the row and column spanning of the item

method.name: SetPos
method.docstring: If the item is already a member of a sizer then first ensure that there is no other item that would intersect with this one at the new position, then set the new position. Returns True if the change is successful and after the next Layout() the item will be moved.

method.name: SetSpan
method.docstring: If the item is already a member of a sizer then first ensure that there is no other item that would intersect with this one with its new spanning size, then set the new spanning. Returns True if the change is successful and after the next Layout() the item will be resized.

method.name: Intersects
method.docstring: Returns True if this item and the other item instersect.

method.name: IntersectsPos
method.autodoc: IntersectsPos(self, GBPosition pos, GBSpan span) -> bool
method.docstring: Returns True if the given pos/span would intersect with this item.

method.name: GetEndPos
method.docstring: Get the row and column of the endpoint of this item.

method.name: GetGBSizer
method.docstring: Get the sizer this item is a member of.

method.name: SetGBSizer
method.docstring: Set the sizer this item is a member of.

class.name: GridBagSizer
class.docstring: A `wx.Sizer` that can lay out items in a virtual grid like a `wx.FlexGridSizer` but in this case explicit positioning of the items is allowed using `wx.GBPosition`, and items can optionally span more than one row and/or column using `wx.GBSpan`. The total size of the virtual grid is determined by the largest row and column that items are positioned at, adjusted for spanning.

constructor.name: GridBagSizer
constructor.docstring: Constructor, with optional parameters to specify the gap between the rows and columns.

method.name: Add
method.autodoc: Add(self, item, GBPosition pos, GBSpan span=DefaultSpan, int flag=0, int border=0, userData=None)
method.docstring:
Adds an item to the sizer at the grid cell *pos*, optionally spanning more than one row or column as specified with *span*. The remaining args behave similarly to `wx.Sizer.Add`.
Returns True if the item was successfully placed at the given cell position, False if something was already there.

method.name: AddItem
method.docstring: Add an item to the sizer using a `wx.GBSizerItem`. Returns True if the item was successfully placed at its given cell position, False if something was already there.

method.name: GetEmptyCellSize
method.docstring: Get the size used for cells in the grid with no item.

method.name: SetEmptyCellSize
method.docstring: Set the size used for cells in the grid with no item.

method.name: GetItemPosition
method.docstring:
GetItemPosition(self, item) -> GBPosition
Get the grid position of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item.

method.name: GetItemPosition
method.docstring:
GetItemPosition(self, item) -> GBPosition
Get the grid position of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item.

method.name: GetItemPosition
method.docstring:
GetItemPosition(self, item) -> GBPosition
Get the grid position of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item.

method.name: SetItemPosition
method.docstring:
SetItemPosition(self, item, GBPosition pos) -> bool
Set the grid position of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item. Returns True on success. If the move is not allowed (because an item is already there) then False is returned.

method.name: SetItemPosition
method.docstring:
SetItemPosition(self, item, GBPosition pos) -> bool
Set the grid position of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item. Returns True on success. If the move is not allowed (because an item is already there) then False is returned.

method.name: SetItemPosition
method.docstring:
SetItemPosition(self, item, GBPosition pos) -> bool
Set the grid position of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item. Returns True on success. If the move is not allowed (because an item is already there) then False is returned.

method.name: GetItemSpan
method.docstring:
GetItemSpan(self, item) -> GBSpan
Get the row/col spanning of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item.

method.name: GetItemSpan
method.docstring:
GetItemSpan(self, item) -> GBSpan
Get the row/col spanning of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item.

method.name: GetItemSpan
method.docstring:
GetItemSpan(self, item) -> GBSpan
Get the row/col spanning of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item.

method.name: SetItemSpan
method.docstring:
SetItemSpan(self, item, GBSpan span) -> bool
Set the row/col spanning of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item. Returns True on success. If the move is not allowed (because an item is already there) then False is returned.

method.name: SetItemSpan
method.docstring:
SetItemSpan(self, item, GBSpan span) -> bool
Set the row/col spanning of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item. Returns True on success. If the move is not allowed (because an item is already there) then False is returned.

method.name: SetItemSpan
method.docstring:
SetItemSpan(self, item, GBSpan span) -> bool
Set the row/col spanning of the specified *item* where *item* is either a window or subsizer that is a member of this sizer, or a zero-based index of an item. Returns True on success. If the move is not allowed (because an item is already there) then False is returned.

method.name: FindItem
method.docstring:
FindItem(self, item) -> GBSizerItem
Find the sizer item for the given window or subsizer, returns None if not found. (non-recursive)

method.name: FindItem
method.docstring:
FindItem(self, item) -> GBSizerItem
Find the sizer item for the given window or subsizer, returns None if not found. (non-recursive)

method.name: FindItemAtPosition
method.docstring: Return the sizer item for the given grid cell, or None if there is no item at that position. (non-recursive)

method.name: FindItemAtPoint
method.docstring: Return the sizer item located at the point given in *pt*, or None if there is no item at that point. The (x,y) coordinates in pt correspond to the client coordinates of the window using the sizer for layout. (non-recursive)

method.name: CheckForIntersection
method.autodoc: CheckForIntersection(self, GBSizerItem item, GBSizerItem excludeItem=None) -> bool
method.docstring: Look at all items and see if any intersect (or would overlap) the given *item*. Returns True if so, False if there would be no overlap. If an *excludeItem* is given then it will not be checked for intersection, for example it may be the item we are checking the position of.

method.name: CheckForIntersectionPos
method.autodoc: CheckForIntersectionPos(self, GBPosition pos, GBSpan span, GBSizerItem excludeItem=None) -> bool
method.docstring: Look at all items and see if any intersect (or would overlap) the given position and span. Returns True if so, False if there would be no overlap. If an *excludeItem* is given then it will not be checked for intersection, for example it may be the item we are checking the position of.

class.name: IndividualLayoutConstraint
class.docstring: Objects of this class are stored in the `wx.LayoutConstraints` class as one of eight possible constraints that a window can be involved in. You will never need to create an instance of wx.IndividualLayoutConstraint, rather you should create a `wx.LayoutConstraints` instance and use the individual contstraints that it contains.

method.name: Set
method.autodoc: Set(self, int rel, Window otherW, int otherE, int val=0, int marg=wxLAYOUT_DEFAULT_MARGIN)
method.docstring: Sets the properties of the constraint. Normally called by one of the convenience functions such as Above, RightOf, SameAs.

method.name: LeftOf
method.docstring: Constrains this edge to be to the left of the given window, with an optional margin. Implicitly, this is relative to the left edge of the other window.

method.name: RightOf
method.docstring: Constrains this edge to be to the right of the given window, with an optional margin. Implicitly, this is relative to the right edge of the other window.

method.name: Above
method.docstring: Constrains this edge to be above the given window, with an optional margin. Implicitly, this is relative to the top edge of the other window.

method.name: Below
method.docstring: Constrains this edge to be below the given window, with an optional margin. Implicitly, this is relative to the bottom edge of the other window.

method.name: SameAs
method.autodoc: SameAs(self, Window otherW, int edge, int marg=0)
method.docstring: Constrains this edge or dimension to be to the same as the edge of the given window, with an optional margin.

method.name: PercentOf
method.autodoc: PercentOf(self, Window otherW, int wh, int per)
method.docstring: Constrains this edge or dimension to be to a percentage of the given window, with an optional margin.

method.name: Absolute
method.docstring: Constrains this edge or dimension to be the given absolute value.

method.name: Unconstrained
method.docstring: Sets this edge or dimension to be unconstrained, that is, dependent on other edges and dimensions from which this value can be deduced.

method.name: AsIs
method.docstring: Sets this edge or constraint to be whatever the window's value is at the moment. If either of the width and height constraints are *as is*, the window will not be resized, but moved instead. This is important when considering panel items which are intended to have a default size, such as a button, which may take its size from the size of the button label.

method.name: ResetIfWin
method.docstring: Reset constraint if it mentions otherWin

method.name: SatisfyConstraint
method.autodoc: SatisfyConstraint(self, LayoutConstraints constraints, Window win) -> bool
method.docstring: Try to satisfy constraint

method.name: GetEdge
method.autodoc: GetEdge(self, int which, Window thisWin, Window other) -> int
method.docstring: Get the value of this edge or dimension, or if this is not determinable, -1.

class.name: LayoutConstraints
class.docstring:
**Note:** constraints are now deprecated and you should use sizers instead.
Objects of this class can be associated with a window to define its layout constraints, with respect to siblings or its parent.
The class consists of the following eight constraints of class wx.IndividualLayoutConstraint, some or all of which should be accessed directly to set the appropriate constraints.
* left: represents the left hand edge of the window * right: represents the right hand edge of the window * top: represents the top edge of the window * bottom: represents the bottom edge of the window * width: represents the width of the window * height: represents the height of the window * centreX: represents the horizontal centre point of the window * centreY: represents the vertical centre point of the window
Most constraints are initially set to have the relationship wxUnconstrained, which means that their values should be calculated by looking at known constraints. The exceptions are width and height, which are set to wxAsIs to ensure that if the user does not specify a constraint, the existing width and height will be used, to be compatible with panel items which often have take a default size. If the constraint is ``wx.AsIs``, the dimension will not be changed.
:see: `wx.IndividualLayoutConstraint`, `wx.Window.SetConstraints`

module.pythoncode:
#----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Use Python's bool constants if available, make some if not try: True except NameError: __builtins__.True = 1==1 __builtins__.False = 1==0 def bool(value): return not not value __builtins__.bool = bool
# workarounds for bad wxRTTI names __wxPyPtrTypeMap['wxGauge95'] = 'wxGauge' __wxPyPtrTypeMap['wxSlider95'] = 'wxSlider' __wxPyPtrTypeMap['wxStatusBar95'] = 'wxStatusBar'
#---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # Load version numbers from __version__... Ensure that major and minor # versions are the same for both wxPython and wxWindows.
from __version__ import * __version__ = VERSION_STRING
assert MAJOR_VERSION == _core_.MAJOR_VERSION, "wxPython/wxWindows version mismatch" assert MINOR_VERSION == _core_.MINOR_VERSION, "wxPython/wxWindows version mismatch" if RELEASE_VERSION != _core_.RELEASE_VERSION: import warnings warnings.warn("wxPython/wxWindows release number mismatch")
#----------------------------------------------------------------------------
class PyDeadObjectError(AttributeError): pass
class _wxPyDeadObject(object): """ Instances of wx objects that are OOR capable will have their __class__ changed to this class when the C++ object is deleted. This should help prevent crashes due to referencing a bogus C++ pointer. """ reprStr = "wxPython wrapper for DELETED %s object! (The C++ object no longer exists.)" attrStr = "The C++ part of the %s object has been deleted, attribute access no longer allowed."
def __repr__(self): if not hasattr(self, "_name"): self._name = "[unknown]" return self.reprStr % self._name
def __getattr__(self, *args): if not hasattr(self, "_name"): self._name = "[unknown]" raise PyDeadObjectError(self.attrStr % self._name)
def __nonzero__(self): return 0
class PyUnbornObjectError(AttributeError): pass
class _wxPyUnbornObject(object): """ Some stock objects are created when the wx._core module is imported, but their C++ instance is not created until the wx.App object is created and initialized. These object instances will temporarily have their __class__ changed to this class so an exception will be raised if they are used before the C++ instance is ready. """
reprStr = "wxPython wrapper for UNBORN object! (The C++ object is not initialized yet.)" attrStr = "The C++ part of this object has not been initialized, attribute access not allowed."
def __repr__(self): #if not hasattr(self, "_name"): # self._name = "[unknown]" return self.reprStr #% self._name
def __getattr__(self, *args): #if not hasattr(self, "_name"): # self._name = "[unknown]" raise PyUnbornObjectError(self.attrStr) # % self._name )
def __nonzero__(self): return 0
#---------------------------------------------------------------------------- _wxPyCallAfterId = None
def CallAfter(callable, *args, **kw): """ Call the specified function after the current and pending event handlers have been completed. This is also good for making GUI method calls from non-GUI threads. Any extra positional or keyword args are passed on to the callable when it is called.
:see: `wx.FutureCall` """ app = wx.GetApp() assert app, 'No wxApp created yet'
global _wxPyCallAfterId if _wxPyCallAfterId is None: _wxPyCallAfterId = wx.NewEventType() app.Connect(-1, -1, _wxPyCallAfterId, lambda event: event.callable(*event.args, **event.kw) ) evt = wx.PyEvent() evt.SetEventType(_wxPyCallAfterId) evt.callable = callable evt.args = args evt.kw = kw wx.PostEvent(app, evt)
#----------------------------------------------------------------------------
class FutureCall: """ A convenience class for wx.Timer, that calls the given callable object once after the given amount of milliseconds, passing any positional or keyword args. The return value of the callable is availbale after it has been run with the `GetResult` method.
If you don't need to get the return value or restart the timer then there is no need to hold a reference to this object. It will hold a reference to itself while the timer is running (the timer has a reference to self.Notify) but the cycle will be broken when the timer completes, automatically cleaning up the wx.FutureCall object.
:see: `wx.CallAfter` """ def __init__(self, millis, callable, *args, **kwargs): self.millis = millis self.callable = callable self.SetArgs(*args, **kwargs) self.runCount = 0 self.running = False self.hasRun = False self.result = None self.timer = None self.Start()
def __del__(self): self.Stop()
def Start(self, millis=None, *args, **kwargs): """ (Re)start the timer """ self.hasRun = False if millis is not None: self.millis = millis if args or kwargs: self.SetArgs(*args, **kwargs) self.Stop() self.timer = wx.PyTimer(self.Notify) self.timer.Start(self.millis, wx.TIMER_ONE_SHOT) self.running = True Restart = Start
def Stop(self): """ Stop and destroy the timer. """ if self.timer is not None: self.timer.Stop() self.timer = None
def GetInterval(self): if self.timer is not None: return self.timer.GetInterval() else: return 0
def IsRunning(self): return self.timer is not None and self.timer.IsRunning()
def SetArgs(self, *args, **kwargs): """ (Re)set the args passed to the callable object. This is useful in conjunction with Restart if you want to schedule a new call to the same callable object but with different parameters. """ self.args = args self.kwargs = kwargs
def HasRun(self): return self.hasRun
def GetResult(self): return self.result
def Notify(self): """ The timer has expired so call the callable. """ if self.callable and getattr(self.callable, 'im_self', True): self.runCount += 1 self.running = False self.result = self.callable(*self.args, **self.kwargs) self.hasRun = True if not self.running: # if it wasn't restarted, then cleanup wx.CallAfter(self.Stop)
#---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # Control which items in this module should be documented by epydoc. # We allow only classes and functions, which will help reduce the size # of the docs by filtering out the zillions of constants, EVT objects, # and etc that don't make much sense by themselves, but are instead # documented (or will be) as part of the classes/functions/methods # where they should be used.
class __DocFilter: """ A filter for epydoc that only allows non-Ptr classes and fucntions, in order to reduce the clutter in the API docs. """ def __init__(self, globals): self._globals = globals
def __call__(self, name): import types obj = self._globals.get(name, None) if type(obj) not in [type, types.ClassType, types.FunctionType, types.BuiltinFunctionType]: return False if name.startswith('_') or name.endswith('Ptr') or name.startswith('EVT'): return False return True
#---------------------------------------------------------------------------- #----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Import other modules in this package that should show up in the # "core" wx namespace from _gdi import * from _windows import * from _controls import * from _misc import *
# Fixup the stock objects since they can't be used yet. (They will be # restored in wx.PyApp.OnInit.) _core_._wxPyFixStockObjects()
#---------------------------------------------------------------------------- #----------------------------------------------------------------------------

class.name: Colour
class.docstring:
A colour is an object representing a combination of Red, Green, and Blue (RGB) intensity values, and is used to determine drawing colours, window colours, etc. Valid RGB values are in the range 0 to 255.
In wxPython there are typemaps that will automatically convert from a colour name, or from a '#RRGGBB' colour hex value string to a wx.Colour object when calling C++ methods that expect a wxColour. This means that the following are all equivallent::
win.SetBackgroundColour(wxColour(0,0,255)) win.SetBackgroundColour('BLUE') win.SetBackgroundColour('#0000FF')
Additional colour names and their coresponding values can be added using `wx.ColourDatabase`. Various system colours (as set in the user's system preferences) can be retrieved with `wx.SystemSettings.GetColour`.

Constructs a colour from red, green and blue values.

class.docstring: A brush is a drawing tool for filling in areas. It is used for painting the background of rectangles, ellipses, etc. when drawing on a `wx.DC`. It has a colour and a style.

method.docstring: Returns the stiple `wx.Bitmap` of the brush. If the brush does not have a wx.STIPPLE style, then the return value may be non-None but an uninitialised bitmap (`wx.Bitmap.Ok` returns False).

method.name: Ok
method.docstring: Returns True if the brush is initialised and valid.

class.name: Bitmap
class.docstring: The wx.Bitmap class encapsulates the concept of a platform-dependent bitmap. It can be either monochrome or colour, and either loaded from a file or created dynamically. A bitmap can be selected into a memory device context (instance of `wx.MemoryDC`). This enables the bitmap to be copied to a window or memory device context using `wx.DC.Blit`, or to be used as a drawing surface.

constructor.name: Bitmap
constructor.docstring: Loads a bitmap from a file.

constructor.name: EmptyBitmap
constructor.autodoc: EmptyBitmap(int width, int height, int depth=-1) -> Bitmap
constructor.docstring: Creates a new bitmap of the given size. A depth of -1 indicates the depth of the current screen or visual. Some platforms only support 1 for monochrome and -1 for the current colour setting.

constructor.name: BitmapFromIcon
constructor.docstring: Create a new bitmap from a `wx.Icon` object.

constructor.name: BitmapFromImage
constructor.docstring: Creates bitmap object from a `wx.Image`. This has to be done to actually display a `wx.Image` as you cannot draw an image directly on a window. The resulting bitmap will use the provided colour depth (or that of the current screen colour depth if depth is -1) which entails that a colour reduction may have to take place.

constructor.name: BitmapFromXPMData
constructor.docstring: Construct a Bitmap from a list of strings formatted as XPM data.

constructor.name: BitmapFromBits
constructor.autodoc: BitmapFromBits(PyObject bits, int width, int height, int depth=1) -> Bitmap
constructor.docstring: Creates a bitmap from an array of bits. You should only use this function for monochrome bitmaps (depth 1) in portable programs: in this case the bits parameter should contain an XBM image. For other bit depths, the behaviour is platform dependent.

method.name: GetWidth
method.docstring: Gets the width of the bitmap in pixels.

method.name: GetHeight
method.docstring: Gets the height of the bitmap in pixels.

method.name: GetDepth
method.docstring: Gets the colour depth of the bitmap. A value of 1 indicates a monochrome bitmap.

method.name: GetSize
method.docstring: Get the size of the bitmap.

method.name: ConvertToImage
method.docstring: Creates a platform-independent image from a platform-dependent bitmap. This preserves mask information so that bitmaps and images can be converted back and forth without loss in that respect.

method.name: GetMask
method.docstring:
Gets the associated mask (if any) which may have been loaded from a file or explpicitly set for the bitmap.
:see: `SetMask`, `wx.Mask`

method.name: SetMask
method.docstring:
Sets the mask for this bitmap.
:see: `GetMask`, `wx.Mask`

method.name: SetMaskColour
method.docstring: Create a Mask based on a specified colour in the Bitmap.

method.name: GetSubBitmap
method.docstring: Returns a sub-bitmap of the current one as long as the rect belongs entirely to the bitmap. This function preserves bit depth and mask information.

method.name: SaveFile
method.autodoc: SaveFile(self, String name, int type, Palette palette=None) -> bool
method.docstring: Saves a bitmap in the named file. See `__init__` for a description of the ``type`` parameter.

method.name: LoadFile
method.autodoc: LoadFile(self, String name, int type) -> bool
method.docstring: Loads a bitmap from a file. See `__init__` for a description of the ``type`` parameter.

method.docstring: Set the height property (does not affect the existing bitmap data).

method.name: SetWidth
method.docstring: Set the width property (does not affect the existing bitmap data).

method.name: SetDepth
method.docstring: Set the depth property (does not affect the existing bitmap data).

method.name: SetSize
method.docstring: Set the bitmap size (does not affect the existing bitmap data).

class.name: Mask
class.docstring:
This class encapsulates a monochrome mask bitmap, where the masked area is black and the unmasked area is white. When associated with a bitmap and drawn in a device context, the unmasked area of the bitmap will be drawn, and the masked area will not be drawn.
A mask may be associated with a `wx.Bitmap`. It is used in `wx.DC.DrawBitmap` or `wx.DC.Blit` when the source device context is a `wx.MemoryDC` with a `wx.Bitmap` selected into it that contains a mask.

constructor.name: Mask
constructor.docstring:
Constructs a mask from a `wx.Bitmap` and a `wx.Colour` in that bitmap that indicates the transparent portions of the mask. In other words, the pixels in ``bitmap`` that match ``colour`` will be the transparent portions of the mask. If no ``colour`` or an invalid ``colour`` is passed then BLACK is used.
:see: `wx.Bitmap`, `wx.Colour`

module.pythoncode: MaskColour = wx._deprecated(Mask, "wx.MaskColour is deprecated, use `wx.Mask` instead.")

class.name: Cursor
class.docstring:
A cursor is a small bitmap usually used for denoting where the mouse pointer is, with a picture that might indicate the interpretation of a mouse click.
A single cursor object may be used in many windows (any subwindow type). The wxWindows convention is to set the cursor for a window, as in X, rather than to set it globally as in MS Windows, although a global `wx.SetCursor` function is also available for use on MS Windows.

constructor.docstring:
Construct a Cursor from a file. Specify the type of file using wx.BITAMP_TYPE* constants, and specify the hotspot if not using a cur file.
This constructor is not available on wxGTK, use ``wx.StockCursor``, ``wx.CursorFromImage``, or ``wx.CursorFromBits`` instead.

constructor.name: StockCursor
constructor.docstring: Create a cursor using one of the stock cursors. Note that not all cursors are available on all platforms.

constructor.name: CursorFromImage
constructor.docstring: Constructs a cursor from a wxImage. The cursor is monochrome, colors with the RGB elements all greater than 127 will be foreground, colors less than this background. The mask (if any) will be used as transparent.

staticmethod.name: GetClassDefaultAttributes
staticmethod.docstring:
Get the default attributes for this class. This is useful if you want to use the same font or colour in your own control as in a standard control -- which is a much better idea than hard coding specific colours or fonts which might look completely out of place on the user's system, especially if it uses themes.
The variant parameter is only relevant under Mac currently and is ignore under other platforms. Under Mac, it will change the size of the returned font. See `wx.Window.SetWindowVariant` for more about this.

method.name: GetWindow1
method.docstring: Gets the only or left/top pane.

method.name: GetWindow2
method.docstring: Gets the right/bottom pane.

method.name: SetSplitMode
method.docstring: Sets the split mode. The mode can be wx.SPLIT_VERTICAL or wx.SPLIT_HORIZONTAL. This only sets the internal variable; does not update the display.

method.name: GetSplitMode
method.docstring: Gets the split mode

method.name: Initialize
method.docstring: Initializes the splitter window to have one pane. This should be called if you wish to initially view only a single pane in the splitter window.

method.name: SplitVertically
method.autodoc: SplitVertically(self, Window window1, Window window2, int sashPosition=0) -> bool
method.docstring: Initializes the left and right panes of the splitter window.

method.name: SplitHorizontally
method.autodoc: SplitHorizontally(self, Window window1, Window window2, int sashPosition=0) -> bool
method.docstring: Initializes the top and bottom panes of the splitter window.

method.name: Unsplit
method.docstring:
Unsplits the window. Pass the pane to remove, or None to remove the right or bottom pane. Returns True if successful, False otherwise (the window was not split).
This function will not actually delete the pane being removed; it sends EVT_SPLITTER_UNSPLIT which can be handled for the desired behaviour. By default, the pane being removed is only hidden.

method.name: ReplaceWindow
method.autodoc: ReplaceWindow(self, Window winOld, Window winNew) -> bool
method.docstring:
This function replaces one of the windows managed by the SplitterWindow with another one. It is in general better to use it instead of calling Unsplit() and then resplitting the window back because it will provoke much less flicker. It is valid to call this function whether the splitter has two windows or only one.
Both parameters should be non-None and winOld must specify one of the windows managed by the splitter. If the parameters are incorrect or the window couldn't be replaced, False is returned. Otherwise the function will return True, but please notice that it will not Destroy the replaced window and you may wish to do it yourself.

method.name: UpdateSize
method.docstring:
Causes any pending sizing of the sash and child panes to take place immediately.
Such resizing normally takes place in idle time, in order to wait for layout to be completed. However, this can cause unacceptable flicker as the panes are resized after the window has been shown. To work around this, you can perform window layout (for example by sending a size event to the parent window), and then call this function, before showing the top-level window.

method.docstring: Is the window split?

method.docstring: Sets the sash size

method.docstring: Sets the border size

method.docstring: Gets the sash size

method.name: GetBorderSize
method.docstring: Gets the border size

method.name: SetSashPosition
method.docstring: Sets the sash position, in pixels. If redraw is Ttrue then the panes are resized and the sash and border are redrawn.

method.name: GetSashPosition
method.docstring: Returns the surrent sash position.

method.name: SetMinimumPaneSize
method.docstring:
Sets the minimum pane size in pixels.
The default minimum pane size is zero, which means that either pane can be reduced to zero by dragging the sash, thus removing one of the panes. To prevent this behaviour (and veto out-of-range sash dragging), set a minimum size, for example 20 pixels. If the wx.SP_PERMIT_UNSPLIT style is used when a splitter window is created, the window may be unsplit even if minimum size is non-zero.

method.name: GetMinimumPaneSize
method.docstring: Gets the minimum pane size in pixels.

method.name: SetSashPosition
method.docstring: This funciton is only meaningful during EVT_SPLITTER_SASH_POS_CHANGING and EVT_SPLITTER_SASH_POS_CHANGED events. In the case of _CHANGED events, sets the the new sash position. In the case of _CHANGING events, sets the new tracking bar position so visual feedback during dragging will represent that change that will actually take place. Set to -1 from the event handler code to prevent repositioning.

method.name: GetSashPosition
method.docstring: Returns the new sash position while in EVT_SPLITTER_SASH_POS_CHANGING and EVT_SPLITTER_SASH_POS_CHANGED events.

method.docstring: Returns a pointer to the window being removed when a splitter window is unsplit.

class.name: ColourData
class.docstring: This class holds a variety of information related to the colour chooser dialog, used to transfer settings and results to and from the `wx.ColourDialog`.

constructor.name: ColourData
constructor.docstring: Constructor, sets default values.

method.name: GetChooseFull
method.docstring: Under Windows, determines whether the Windows colour dialog will display the full dialog with custom colour selection controls. Has no meaning under other platforms. The default value is true.

method.name: GetColour
method.docstring: Gets the colour (pre)selected by the dialog.

method.name: GetCustomColour
method.docstring: Gets the i'th custom colour associated with the colour dialog. i should be an integer between 0 and 15. The default custom colours are all invalid colours.

method.name: SetChooseFull
method.docstring: Under Windows, tells the Windows colour dialog to display the full dialog with custom colour selection controls. Under other platforms, has no effect. The default value is true.

method.name: SetColour
method.docstring: Sets the default colour for the colour dialog. The default colour is black.

method.name: SetCustomColour
method.docstring: Sets the i'th custom colour for the colour dialog. i should be an integer between 0 and 15. The default custom colours are all invalid colours.

method.docstring:
Sets the wildcard, which can contain multiple file types, for example::
"BMP files (*.bmp)|*.bmp|GIF files (*.gif)|*.gif"

method.name: SetStyle
method.docstring: Sets the dialog style.

method.name: SetFilterIndex
method.docstring: Sets the default filter index, starting from zero.

method.name: GetMessage
method.docstring: Returns the message that will be displayed on the dialog.

method.name: GetPath
method.docstring: Returns the full path (directory and filename) of the selected file.

method.name: GetDirectory
method.docstring: Returns the default directory.

method.name: GetFilename
method.docstring: Returns the default filename.

method.name: GetWildcard
method.docstring: Returns the file dialog wildcard.

method.name: GetStyle
method.docstring: Returns the dialog style.

method.name: GetFilterIndex
method.docstring: Returns the index into the list of filters supplied, optionally, in the wildcard parameter. Before the dialog is shown, this is the index which will be used when the dialog is first displayed. After the dialog is shown, this is the index selected by the user.

method.name: GetFilenames
method.docstring: Returns a list of filenames chosen in the dialog. This function should only be used with the dialogs which have wx.MULTIPLE style, use GetFilename for the others.

method.name: GetPaths
method.docstring: Fills the array paths with the full paths of the files chosen. This function should only be used with the dialogs which have wx.MULTIPLE style, use GetPath for the others.

constructor.docstring: Constructor. Use ShowModal method to show the dialog.

class.name: FontData
class.docstring: This class holds a variety of information related to font dialogs and is used to transfer settings to and results from a `wx.FontDialog`.

constructor.name: FontData
constructor.docstring: This class holds a variety of information related to font dialogs and is used to transfer settings to and results from a `wx.FontDialog`.

method.name: EnableEffects
method.docstring: Enables or disables 'effects' under MS Windows only. This refers to the controls for manipulating colour, strikeout and underline properties. The default value is true.

method.name: GetAllowSymbols
method.docstring: Under MS Windows, returns a flag determining whether symbol fonts can be selected. Has no effect on other platforms. The default value is true.

method.name: GetColour
method.docstring: Gets the colour associated with the font dialog. The default value is black.

method.name: GetChosenFont
method.docstring: Gets the font chosen by the user.

method.name: GetEnableEffects
method.docstring: Determines whether 'effects' are enabled under Windows.

method.name: GetInitialFont
method.docstring: Gets the font that will be initially used by the font dialog. This should have previously been set by the application.

method.name: GetShowHelp
method.docstring: Returns true if the Help button will be shown (Windows only). The default value is false.

method.name: SetAllowSymbols
method.docstring: Under MS Windows, determines whether symbol fonts can be selected. Has no effect on other platforms. The default value is true.

method.name: SetChosenFont
method.docstring: Sets the font that will be returned to the user (normally for internal use only).

method.name: SetColour
method.docstring: Sets the colour that will be used for the font foreground colour. The default colour is black.

method.name: SetInitialFont
method.docstring: Sets the font that will be initially used by the font dialog.

method.name: SetRange
method.docstring: Sets the valid range for the font point size (Windows only). The default is 0, 0 (unrestricted range).

method.name: SetShowHelp
method.docstring: Determines whether the Help button will be displayed in the font dialog (Windows only). The default value is false.

class.name: FontDialog
class.docstring:
wx.FontDialog allows the user to select a system font and its attributes.
:see: `wx.FontData`

constructor.name: FontDialog
constructor.docstring: Constructor. Pass a parent window and the `wx.FontData` object to be used to initialize the dialog controls. Call `ShowModal` to display the dialog. If ShowModal returns ``wx.ID_OK`` then you can fetch the results with via the `wx.FontData` returned by `GetFontData`.

method.name: GetFontData
method.docstring: Returns a reference to the internal `wx.FontData` used by the wx.FontDialog.

class.name: MessageDialog
class.docstring: This class provides a simple dialog that shows a single or multi-line message, with a choice of OK, Yes, No and/or Cancel buttons.

constructor.name: MessageDialog
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, Window parent, String message, String caption=MessageBoxCaptionStr, long style=wxOK|wxCANCEL|wxCENTRE, Point pos=DefaultPosition) -> MessageDialog
constructor.docstring: Constructor, use `ShowModal` to display the dialog.

class.name: ProgressDialog
class.docstring: A dialog that shows a short message and a progress bar. Optionally, it can display an ABORT button.

constructor.name: ProgressDialog
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, String title, String message, int maximum=100, Window parent=None, int style=wxPD_AUTO_HIDE|wxPD_APP_MODAL) -> ProgressDialog
constructor.docstring: Constructor. Creates the dialog, displays it and disables user input for other windows, or, if wx.PD_APP_MODAL flag is not given, for its parent window only.

method.name: Update
method.autodoc: Update(self, int value, String newmsg=EmptyString) -> bool
method.docstring:
Updates the dialog, setting the progress bar to the new value and, if given changes the message above it. Returns true unless the Cancel button has been pressed.
If false is returned, the application can either immediately destroy the dialog or ask the user for the confirmation and if the abort is not confirmed the dialog may be resumed with Resume function.

method.name: Resume
method.docstring: Can be used to continue with the dialog, after the user had chosen to abort.

module.pythoncode:
EVT_FIND = wx.PyEventBinder( wxEVT_COMMAND_FIND, 1 ) EVT_FIND_NEXT = wx.PyEventBinder( wxEVT_COMMAND_FIND_NEXT, 1 ) EVT_FIND_REPLACE = wx.PyEventBinder( wxEVT_COMMAND_FIND_REPLACE, 1 ) EVT_FIND_REPLACE_ALL = wx.PyEventBinder( wxEVT_COMMAND_FIND_REPLACE_ALL, 1 ) EVT_FIND_CLOSE = wx.PyEventBinder( wxEVT_COMMAND_FIND_CLOSE, 1 )
# For backwards compatibility. Should they be removed? EVT_COMMAND_FIND = EVT_FIND EVT_COMMAND_FIND_NEXT = EVT_FIND_NEXT EVT_COMMAND_FIND_REPLACE = EVT_FIND_REPLACE EVT_COMMAND_FIND_REPLACE_ALL = EVT_FIND_REPLACE_ALL EVT_COMMAND_FIND_CLOSE = EVT_FIND_CLOSE

method.docstring: Get the currently selected flags: this is the combination of wx.FR_DOWN, wx.FR_WHOLEWORD and wx.FR_MATCHCASE flags.

method.docstring: Return the string to find (never empty).

method.name: GetReplaceString
method.docstring: Return the string to replace the search string with (only for replace and replace all events).

method.name: GetDialog
method.docstring: Return the pointer to the dialog which generated this event.

class.name: FindReplaceData
class.docstring:
wx.FindReplaceData holds the data for wx.FindReplaceDialog. It is used to initialize the dialog with the default values and will keep the last values from the dialog when it is closed. It is also updated each time a `wx.FindDialogEvent` is generated so instead of using the `wx.FindDialogEvent` methods you can also directly query this object.
Note that all SetXXX() methods may only be called before showing the dialog and calling them has no effect later.

constructor.name: FindReplaceData
constructor.docstring: Constuctor initializes the flags to default value (0).

method.name: GetFindString
method.docstring: Get the string to find.

method.name: GetReplaceString
method.docstring: Get the replacement string.

method.name: GetFlags
method.docstring: Get the combination of flag values.

method.name: SetFlags
method.docstring: Set the flags to use to initialize the controls of the dialog.

method.name: SetFindString
method.docstring: Set the string to find (used as initial value by the dialog).

method.name: SetReplaceString
method.docstring: Set the replacement string (used as initial value by the dialog).

class.name: FindReplaceDialog
class.docstring: wx.FindReplaceDialog is a standard modeless dialog which is used to allow the user to search for some text (and possibly replace it with something else). The actual searching is supposed to be done in the owner window which is the parent of this dialog. Note that it means that unlike for the other standard dialogs this one must have a parent window. Also note that there is no way to use this dialog in a modal way; it is always, by design and implementation, modeless.

module.pythoncode: wx = _core

class.name: Button
class.docstring: A button is a control that contains a text string, and is one of the most common elements of a GUI. It may be placed on a dialog box or panel, or indeed almost any other window.

constructor.name: Button
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, Window parent, int id=-1, String label=EmptyString, Point pos=DefaultPosition, Size size=DefaultSize, long style=0, Validator validator=DefaultValidator, String name=ButtonNameStr) -> Button
constructor.docstring: Create and show a button.

constructor.name: PreButton
constructor.docstring: Precreate a Button for 2-phase creation.

method.name: Create
method.autodoc: Create(self, Window parent, int id=-1, String label=EmptyString, Point pos=DefaultPosition, Size size=DefaultSize, long style=0, Validator validator=DefaultValidator, String name=ButtonNameStr) -> bool
method.docstring: Acutally create the GUI Button for 2-phase creation.

method.name: SetDefault
method.docstring: This sets the button to be the default item for the panel or dialog box.

staticmethod.name: GetDefaultSize
staticmethod.docstring: Returns the default button size for this platform.

staticmethod.name: GetClassDefaultAttributes
staticmethod.docstring:
Get the default attributes for this class. This is useful if you want to use the same font or colour in your own control as in a standard control -- which is a much better idea than hard coding specific colours or fonts which might look completely out of place on the user's system, especially if it uses themes.
The variant parameter is only relevant under Mac currently and is ignore under other platforms. Under Mac, it will change the size of the returned font. See `wx.Window.SetWindowVariant` for more about this.

class.name: BitmapButton
class.docstring: A Button that contains a bitmap. A bitmap button can be supplied with a single bitmap, and wxWidgets will draw all button states using this bitmap. If the application needs more control, additional bitmaps for the selected state, unpressed focused state, and greyed-out state may be supplied.

constructor.name: BitmapButton
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, Window parent, int id=-1, Bitmap bitmap=wxNullBitmap, Point pos=DefaultPosition, Size size=DefaultSize, long style=BU_AUTODRAW, Validator validator=DefaultValidator, String name=ButtonNameStr) -> BitmapButton
constructor.docstring: Create and show a button with a bitmap for the label.

constructor.name: PreBitmapButton
constructor.docstring: Precreate a BitmapButton for 2-phase creation.

method.name: Create
method.autodoc: Create(self, Window parent, int id=-1, Bitmap bitmap=wxNullBitmap, Point pos=DefaultPosition, Size size=DefaultSize, long style=BU_AUTODRAW, Validator validator=DefaultValidator, String name=ButtonNameStr) -> bool
method.docstring: Acutally create the GUI BitmapButton for 2-phase creation.

method.name: GetBitmapLabel
method.docstring: Returns the label bitmap (the one passed to the constructor).

method.name: GetBitmapDisabled
method.docstring: Returns the bitmap for the disabled state.

method.name: GetBitmapFocus
method.docstring: Returns the bitmap for the focused state.

method.name: GetBitmapSelected
method.docstring: Returns the bitmap for the selected state.

method.name: SetBitmapDisabled
method.docstring: Sets the bitmap for the disabled button appearance.

method.name: SetBitmapFocus
method.docstring: Sets the bitmap for the button appearance when it has the keyboard focus.

method.name: SetBitmapSelected
method.docstring: Sets the bitmap for the selected (depressed) button appearance.

method.name: SetBitmapLabel
method.docstring: Sets the bitmap label for the button. This is the bitmap used for the unselected state, and for all other states if no other bitmaps are provided.

class.name: CheckBox
class.docstring: A checkbox is a labelled box which by default is either on (the checkmark is visible) or off (no checkmark). Optionally (When the wx.CHK_3STATE style flag is set) it can have a third state, called the mixed or undetermined state. Often this is used as a "Does Not Apply" state.

constructor.name: CheckBox
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, Window parent, int id=-1, String label=EmptyString, Point pos=DefaultPosition, Size size=DefaultSize, long style=0, Validator validator=DefaultValidator, String name=CheckBoxNameStr) -> CheckBox
constructor.docstring: Creates and shows a CheckBox control

constructor.name: PreCheckBox
constructor.docstring: Precreate a CheckBox for 2-phase creation.

method.name: Create
method.autodoc: Create(self, Window parent, int id=-1, String label=EmptyString, Point pos=DefaultPosition, Size size=DefaultSize, long style=0, Validator validator=DefaultValidator, String name=CheckBoxNameStr) -> bool
method.docstring: Actually create the GUI CheckBox for 2-phase creation.

method.name: GetValue
method.docstring: Gets the state of a 2-state CheckBox. Returns True if it is checked, False otherwise.

method.name: IsChecked
method.docstring: Similar to GetValue, but raises an exception if it is not a 2-state CheckBox.

method.name: SetValue
method.docstring: Set the state of a 2-state CheckBox. Pass True for checked, False for unchecked.

method.name: Get3StateValue
method.docstring: Returns wx.CHK_UNCHECKED when the CheckBox is unchecked, wx.CHK_CHECKED when it is checked and wx.CHK_UNDETERMINED when it's in the undetermined state. Raises an exceptiion when the function is used with a 2-state CheckBox.

method.name: Set3StateValue
method.docstring: Sets the CheckBox to the given state. The state parameter can be one of the following: wx.CHK_UNCHECKED (Check is off), wx.CHK_CHECKED (the Check is on) or wx.CHK_UNDETERMINED (Check is mixed). Raises an exception when the CheckBox is a 2-state checkbox and setting the state to wx.CHK_UNDETERMINED.

method.name: Is3State
method.docstring: Returns whether or not the CheckBox is a 3-state CheckBox.

method.name: Is3rdStateAllowedForUser
method.docstring: Returns whether or not the user can set the CheckBox to the third state.

staticmethod.name: GetClassDefaultAttributes
staticmethod.docstring:
Get the default attributes for this class. This is useful if you want to use the same font or colour in your own control as in a standard control -- which is a much better idea than hard coding specific colours or fonts which might look completely out of place on the user's system, especially if it uses themes.
The variant parameter is only relevant under Mac currently and is ignore under other platforms. Under Mac, it will change the size of the returned font. See `wx.Window.SetWindowVariant` for more about this.

class.docstring: A Choice control is used to select one of a list of strings. Unlike a `wx.ListBox`, only the selection is visible until the user pulls down the menu of choices.

class.name: ComboBox
class.docstring:
A combobox is like a combination of an edit control and a listbox. It can be displayed as static list with editable or read-only text field; or a drop-down list with text field.
A combobox permits a single selection only. Combobox items are numbered from zero.

staticmethod.name: GetClassDefaultAttributes
staticmethod.docstring:
Get the default attributes for this class. This is useful if you want to use the same font or colour in your own control as in a standard control -- which is a much better idea than hard coding specific colours or fonts which might look completely out of place on the user's system, especially if it uses themes.
The variant parameter is only relevant under Mac currently and is ignore under other platforms. Under Mac, it will change the size of the returned font. See `wx.Window.SetWindowVariant` for more about this.

class.name: HelpEvent
class.docstring:
A help event is sent when the user has requested context-sensitive help. This can either be caused by the application requesting context-sensitive help mode via wx.ContextHelp, or (on MS Windows) by the system generating a WM_HELP message when the user pressed F1 or clicked on the query button in a dialog caption.
A help event is sent to the window that the user clicked on, and is propagated up the window hierarchy until the event is processed or there are no more event handlers. The application should call event.GetId to check the identity of the clicked-on window, and then either show some suitable help or call event.Skip if the identifier is unrecognised. Calling Skip is important because it allows wxWindows to generate further events for ancestors of the clicked-on window. Otherwise it would be impossible to show help for container windows, since processing would stop after the first window found.

constructor.name: HelpEvent
constructor.autodoc: __init__(self, wxEventType type=wxEVT_NULL, int winid=0, Point pt=DefaultPosition) -> HelpEvent

method.name: GetPosition
method.docstring: Returns the left-click position of the mouse, in screen coordinates. This allows the application to position the help appropriately.

method.name: SetPosition
method.docstring: Sets the left-click position of the mouse, in screen coordinates.

method.docstring: Get an optional link to further help

method.name: SetLink
method.docstring: Set an optional link to further help

method.name: SetTarget
